study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of an egg-breakfast (higher protein quality) versus a cereal-breakfast (lower protein quality) on appetite hormones, glucose, insulin, satiety, and energy intake in women with overweight or obesity.
results_summary: Experiment-1 showed no significant differences in outcome variables between the two breakfasts. In Experiment-2, the egg-breakfast increased fullness compared to the cereal-breakfast when an appealing food was included in lunch.
population_specificity: 30 otherwise healthy women with overweight or obesity.
effective_dosage: Not specified (breakfast meals of similar energy density and protein quantity).
study_duration: Two weeks per intervention (one week per breakfast type in a crossover design).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the metabolic availability of methionine in lentils and evaluate the effects of combining lentils with rice on protein quality, using egg protein as a reference.
results_summary: The study found that the metabolic availability of methionine in lentils was 69%, and combining lentils with rice reduced phenylalanine oxidation by up to 16%, improving protein quality. Egg protein served as a reference but was not the primary focus of the study.
population_specificity: Five healthy young men (age <30, BMI <25).
effective_dosage: Reference diet included 0.5, 1, 2, and 3 mg·kg⁻¹·d⁻¹ of L-methionine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an egg ovalbumin-derived protein hydrolysate could reduce blood pressure and modify cardiovascular risk in adults with high-normal blood pressure.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in office or central blood pressure, arterial stiffness, blood lipid, or glucose concentrations after 6 weeks of supplementation with the egg protein hydrolysate compared to placebo. The results did not support the hypothesis that the supplement reduces cardiovascular risk in this population.
population_specificity: Adults aged 50-70 years with systolic blood pressure between 130-150 mmHg.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how maternal dietary egg ingestion during early lactation influences egg protein (ovalbumin) levels in breastmilk and its potential effects on infant immune tolerance.
results_summary: Higher maternal egg consumption was associated with increased ovalbumin levels in breastmilk and elevated infant egg-specific IgG4 levels, suggesting a potential role in promoting immune tolerance. No detectable associations were found between mammary epithelium permeability and ovalbumin concentrations.
population_specificity: Lactating women and their infants during the first six weeks of lactation.
effective_dosage: High-egg diet (>4 eggs/week), low-egg diet (1-3 eggs/week), or egg-free diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate early T-cell responses to egg proteins in relation to egg exposure patterns and subsequent IgE-mediated egg allergy in infants.
results_summary: Infants who later developed egg allergy showed elevated Th2 cytokine responses to egg proteins at 4 months, which predicted allergy at 12 months. Early egg introduction did not significantly alter these responses.
population_specificity: Infants with eczema at 4 months of age (n=40 initially, n=58 at 12 months).
effective_dosage: Not specified (early egg exposure vs. placebo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety of live attenuated influenza vaccine (LAIV), which contains egg protein, in young people with egg allergy.
results_summary: The study found no systemic allergic reactions to LAIV in young people with egg allergy, with only mild local symptoms in 1.2% of participants. The vaccine was well tolerated in those with well-controlled asthma or recurrent wheeze, with no hospital admissions or increased respiratory symptoms post-vaccination.
population_specificity: Young people (2-18 years) with egg allergy, including those with previous anaphylaxis and asthma or recurrent wheeze.
study_duration: Immediate observation for 30 minutes post-vaccination, follow-up at 72 hours, and additional follow-up at four weeks for participants with asthma or recurrent wheeze.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical and allergic characteristics of children with egg protein allergy (EA) undergoing oral immunotherapy (OIT) with pasteurized raw egg white and identify factors differentiating patients who tolerate cooked egg white.
results_summary: The study found that children with persistent egg allergy had a median IgE specific to egg white titer of 38.5kU/l, and 14.8% experienced severe reactions due to dietary transgressions. An IgE specific to ovomucoid titer of <2.045kU/l differentiated patients who tolerated cooked egg white, with mean symptom-provoking doses of 1.26g (cooked) and 0.55g (raw).
population_specificity: Children with egg protein allergy (median age six years), 93% of whom had other allergies (58% asthma, 38.6% allergy to more than two food groups).
effective_dosage: Mean symptom-provoking doses: 1.26g (cooked egg white), 0.55g (pasteurized raw egg white).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the safety and efficacy of an egg oral immunotherapy (OIT) protocol in inducing desensitization in egg-allergic children and to compare immune profiles between allergic and nonallergic children.
results_summary: The OIT protocol enabled 60% of allergic children to tolerate 32 mL of egg white, with significant increases in egg-specific IgG4 and IL-10, decreases in IgE, and a shift toward a nonallergic immune profile. Allergic children initially showed a TH2 cytokine bias, which shifted toward a nonallergic phenotype post-OIT.
population_specificity: Children with or without egg allergy.
effective_dosage: Weekly doses of egg protein followed by a maintenance phase (specific amounts not detailed).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether children with egg allergy could safely receive influenza vaccination despite the vaccine containing small amounts of egg protein.
results_summary: The study found that children with even severe egg allergy could safely receive the influenza vaccine, reducing their risk of morbidity and mortality associated with influenza. Recent studies supported this conclusion, demonstrating no significant adverse effects.
population_specificity: Children with a history of egg allergy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a tryptophan-rich dietary supplement derived from egg protein hydrolysate could improve emotional and cognitive functions, mood state, and sleep quality as an alternative to pharmacological treatments for mood disorders.
results_summary: The supplement shifted emotional processing away from negative stimuli, reduced attention to negative emotional stimuli, and increased arousal-like symptoms. It also improved feelings of happiness before bedtime when taken 60-90 minutes prior.
population_specificity: 59 mentally and physically healthy women aged 45-65 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety of the live attenuated influenza vaccine (LAIV), which contains egg protein, in children with egg allergy.
results_summary: The study found no systemic allergic reactions to LAIV in children with egg allergy, including those with prior anaphylaxis. Mild self-limiting symptoms occurred in a small subset, and lower respiratory tract symptoms were reported in 9.4% of participants, none requiring medical intervention beyond routine treatment.
population_specificity: Children aged 2-17 years with egg allergy, including those with asthma/recurrent wheezing (67%) and prior anaphylaxis to egg (41%).
effective_dosage: Not specified (single dose of LAIV administered).
study_duration: Observation for 1 hour post-administration, with follow-up at 72 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of introducing heated egg protein into the diet of allergic patients to induce tolerance acquisition.
results_summary: The study suggests that introducing heated egg protein may help allergic patients develop tolerance, though the exact timing and method of reintroduction remain unclear. Further research is needed to establish definitive guidelines.
population_specificity: Children with cow's milk protein allergy (CMPA) and egg allergy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to inform physicians about hypersensitivity reactions to common vaccine components, including egg protein (ovalbumin), and guide vaccine choice in patients with suspected hypersensitivity.
results_summary: The study listed egg protein (ovalbumin) among vaccine components that may cause hypersensitivity reactions but did not specifically evaluate its safety or efficacy. No direct findings on egg protein's effects were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with suspected hypersensitivity to vaccine components.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the success of oral and sublingual immunotherapy (OIT) in desensitizing and developing tolerance to egg protein in individuals with IgE-mediated egg allergy, compared to placebo or avoidance strategies.
results_summary: OIT showed higher rates of tolerance to full (39% vs. 11.9%) and partial (40% vs. 11.9%) egg servings compared to controls, but 69% of OIT participants experienced mild-to-severe adverse effects, with 5 requiring epinephrine. The evidence quality was low, and long-term tolerance remains uncertain.
population_specificity: Children aged 4 to 15 years with IgE-mediated egg allergy.
effective_dosage: Different OIT protocols were used across studies (specific dosages not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the consistency of gastric emptying measurements using egg protein substitute in patients with gastroparesis (Gp) or functional dyspepsia (FD).
results_summary: The study found that the 320 kcal (30% fat) scintigraphic test using egg protein provided consistent diagnoses in over 85% of cases, suggesting it is a reliable standard for evaluating gastric emptying disorders. The test also reclassified ~40% of patients between Gp and FD.
population_specificity: Symptomatic patients with gastroparesis (Gp) or functional dyspepsia (FD) with documented slow or normal gastric emptying.

study_goal: The study does not examine the safety, efficacy, or quality of eggs; it critiques policymaking approaches to health equity.
results_summary: The study does not provide results related to eggs; it discusses policy paradoxes and calls for upstream economic interventions to address health inequalities.
population_specificity: Not specified (policy-focused commentary)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess antibiotic treatment practices and detect antibiotic residues in guinea fowl eggs from farms in the Savannah region of Togo.
results_summary: The study found that 49.43% of egg samples contained antibiotic residues, with poor adherence to withdrawal periods and widespread self-medication among farmers. Biosecurity and confinement were positively associated with residue presence.
population_specificity: Guinea fowl farmers in the Oti, Tone, and Tandjoare prefectures of Togo.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and immunologic outcomes of an individualized egg oral immunotherapy (OIT) dosing strategy in children with persistent egg allergy.
results_summary: All 6 patients who completed the protocol developed clinical tolerance to egg, with significant reductions in IgE levels and increases in IgG4 levels, alongside decreased skin prick test reactivity. The study also noted transient increases in anti-inflammatory cytokines and a reduced T(H)2:T(H)1 cytokine ratio.
population_specificity: Children aged 3 to 13 years with clinical egg allergy.
effective_dosage: Gradually increased daily doses of egg protein based on egg white IgE levels (specific amounts not detailed).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated (follow-up included a food challenge 1 month post-protocol).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a refrigeration-free preservation method using limonene vapor to extend quail egg shelf life and enhance safety by reducing bacterial contamination.
results_summary: Limonene vapor (0.08%) at 4°C with UV reduced Salmonella Enteritidis and S. aureus by 6-7 log10 on eggshells, maintaining safety standards for 10 days at 30°C. The method caused bacterial cell deformation and pore formation without significant membrane damage.
population_specificity: Quail eggs

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify differences in contamination levels of Toxocara eggs in public parks and determine the primary sources of contamination.
results_summary: The study found significant differences in egg density between parks, with park entrances being the most heavily contaminated, followed by playgrounds. Most recovered eggs were identified as T. canis, indicating dogs as the primary source of contamination.
population_specificity: Public parks in Dublin City.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the presence of antibiotic residues in hen's eggs and other animal-derived foodstuffs from farms in Umbria and Marche regions (Italy).
results_summary: Out of 2,354 samples analyzed (including eggs), 15 tested positive for antibiotic residues, but all were below the EU maximum residue limits and deemed compliant. The study highlights the potential public health risk of antibiotic residues contributing to antimicrobial resistance.
population_specificity: Hen's eggs and other animal-derived foodstuffs from 444 farms in Umbria and Marche regions (Italy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate a gas-phase hydroxyl-radical process as an effective egg disinfection method to reduce Salmonella and other pathogens while preserving egg integrity and embryo viability.
results_summary: The hydroxyl-radical treatment (HR) effectively eliminated Salmonella, Escherichia coli, and Enterococcus faecium (>5 log CFU/egg reduction) but left residual TAC. The enhanced treatment (HRS) achieved surface sterilization and reduced Aspergillus niger spores. Both treatments maintained hatching rates (64-74%) and improved hatch-to-fertility ratios (89-97%) compared to controls (80%), with no significant differences in seven-day mortality or feed conversion ratios.
population_specificity: Fertile hatchery eggs (n=50 per treatment group).
effective_dosage: HR (2% hydrogen peroxide, 20 ppm ozone, 19 mJ/cm² UV-C); HRS (3% hydrogen peroxide, 20 ppm ozone, 114 mJ/cm² UV-C, pre-treated with 13.75 mM riboflavin and 3% hydrogen peroxide at 70°C).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of heat treatments in killing spotted lanternfly and spongy moth eggs at various temperatures and exposure times.
results_summary: No eggs hatched when exposed to temperatures ≥60°C for over 15 minutes. Spotted lanternfly egg hatch declined at ≥45°C, while spongy moth eggs showed reduced hatch at ≥50°C. Spongy moth eggs were more vulnerable in fall than spring.
population_specificity: Spotted lanternfly and spongy moth eggs (collected from field sites and lab-reared colonies).
effective_dosage: Temperature exposures ranged from 35-70°C for 15-135 minutes.
study_duration: Heat treatments were applied in spring 2023 and spring/fall 2024.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a novel cooking method for eggs that simultaneously cooks the albumen and yolk at different temperatures without separation, optimizing texture and nutrients.
results_summary: The study found that periodic cooking allows for different cooking extents and protein denaturation variations in albumen and yolk, improving texture and nutrient retention compared to traditional methods. Sensory, texture, and spectroscopic analyses confirmed the effectiveness of the new approach.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely general egg cooking applications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and compare the functional metabolite components of pigeon, chicken, and quail eggs to understand their potential nutritional differences.
results_summary: The study identified 692 metabolites across the three egg types, with 263 significantly differentially abundant metabolites between pigeon eggs and both chicken and quail eggs. Pigeon eggs showed higher levels of lipids, lipid-like molecules, nucleosides, and nucleotides, suggesting potential benefits for glucose and lipid metabolism-related diseases.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or animal study implied by metabolite analysis).

study_goal: The researchers investigated a case of foodborne botulism caused by homemade pickled eggs contaminated with C. botulinum.
results_summary: Five individuals showed symptoms of botulism, while three were asymptomatic. All patients received antitoxin treatment, and no deaths occurred; phylogenetic analysis confirmed a common origin for the C. botulinum isolates.
population_specificity: Individuals consuming homemade pickled eggs in Weihai, China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the residue elimination patterns of seven antibiotics in the eggs of Taihang chickens and determine suitable withdrawal times (WDTs) to ensure safety.
results_summary: The study found that residues of five antibiotics (oxytetracycline, chlortetracycline, tylosin, tylvalosin, and tiamulin) were below maximum residue limits (MRLs), with recommended WDTs ranging from 0 to 8 days. Erythromycin and lincomycin required longer WDTs (11 and 9 days, respectively) to fall below MRLs.
population_specificity: 240 healthy Taihang chickens, aged 180 days, under free-range conditions.
effective_dosage: Maximum dosages and longest durations of treatment recommended by the Veterinary Pharmacopoeia of the People's Republic of China.
study_duration: Continued until no drug residue could be detected.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the contamination of Opisthorchis viverrini eggs in underwater sediments and evaluate the effectiveness of health interventions in reducing opisthorchiasis transmission in endemic areas.
results_summary: O. viverrini eggs were found in canal sediments, correlating with higher human and fish infection rates. Health interventions from 2019 to 2023 significantly reduced egg contamination, human opisthorchiasis prevalence, and metacercariae infection in fish.
population_specificity: Residents and aquatic environments in UdonThani municipality, Northeast Thailand.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether IVF treatment using a woman's own eggs could result in a successful pregnancy and live birth in a 48-year-old woman.
results_summary: The study reported a successful clinical pregnancy and live birth in a 48-year-old woman using her own eggs and a euploid embryo during her first IVF attempt, suggesting that limited attempts with older women's own eggs may be viable in specific cases.
population_specificity: A 48-year-old woman undergoing IVF treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of daily egg intake on environmental enteric dysfunction (EED) biomarkers and its association with growth faltering in infants.
results_summary: Daily egg intake significantly reduced fibroblast growth factor 21 (FGF21) levels, indicating decreased growth hormone resistance, but higher baseline FGF21 and I-FABP levels were linked to increased growth faltering. IGF-1 was positively associated with improved growth indicators, while FGF21 and I-FABP were associated with higher odds of stunting, wasting, and being underweight.
population_specificity: Infants aged 6-9 months in Jouberton, South Africa.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether incubation temperature and prenatal corticosterone exposure interact to affect development, physiology, and life-history traits in the delicate skink.
results_summary: Incubation temperature and corticosterone treatment independently reduced body size at hatching, with effects persisting into adulthood. Cool incubation temperatures and low corticosterone doses led to higher baseline corticosterone levels and more efficient mitochondria in adults, but no interactive effects were found.
population_specificity: Delicate skink (Lampropholis delicata) eggs and subsequent hatchlings to adulthood.
effective_dosage: High or low doses of corticosterone (specific amounts not provided).
study_duration: From egg incubation through hatching to adulthood (specific duration not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of paraformaldehyde levels on disinfection efficacy and embryo development in fertile eggs used for vaccine production.
results_summary: Paraformaldehyde disinfection significantly reduced bacterial counts in fertile eggs, with 3 g/m³ being the most effective concentration. Optimal bacterial reduction was achieved at 6.07 g/m³, while 2.67 g/m³ yielded the best embryo length.
population_specificity: Fertile eggs from breeders intended for vaccine production.
study_duration: Disinfection followed by incubation, assessed on the 10th day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an AI-assisted platform (YOLOv4) for detecting and classifying human parasite eggs in diagnostic settings.
results_summary: The AI model achieved high recognition accuracy, with 100% for some species (e.g., Clonorchis sinensis and Schistosoma japonicum) and slightly lower but still robust accuracies for others (e.g., 84.85% for Trichuris trichiura). Mixed helminth egg recognition also showed strong performance, though with some variability.
population_specificity: Human parasite eggs (e.g., Ascaris lumbricoides, Trichuris trichiura, etc.) in diagnostic samples.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of a high-voltage pulsed electric field in killing raisin parasitic eggs, specifically Plodia interpunctella eggs.
results_summary: The study found that at an output voltage of 22.8 kV, delivery speed of 0.024 m/s, and electric field frequency of 3.8 Hz, the unhatched rate of eggs was 68.14%, and the larval survival rate was 20.36%. These results suggest the method is moderately effective in reducing egg viability.
population_specificity: Plodia interpunctella eggs on raisin surfaces.
effective_dosage: Output voltage of 22.8 kV, delivery speed of 0.024 m/s, electric field frequency of 3.8 Hz.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the duration of Dioctophyme renale egg elimination in dog urine after surgical removal of the nematodes.
results_summary: The study found that 93.3% of dogs continued to eliminate D. renale eggs for at least ten days post-surgery, with peak elimination on the first postoperative day, indicating that dogs remain potential sources of infection even after parasite removal.
population_specificity: 15 dogs with D. renale infection in their kidneys.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of the lipophorin receptor in lipid transport and its impact on egg viability and reproduction in the kissing bug Rhodnius prolixus.
results_summary: Lipophorin receptor knockdown delayed egg laying, reduced triacylglycerol in eggs, altered gene expression in ovaries and fat body, and caused egg collapse, darkening, and deformed nymphs. The receptor is not essential for lipid physiology but is crucial for egg viability and reproduction.
population_specificity: Kissing bug (Rhodnius prolixus)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the quality and safety of eggs pasteurized using radio frequency (RF) heating compared to conventional methods.
results_summary: RF-treated eggs showed no significant changes in quality parameters (Haugh unit, yolk index, compression strength, etc.) or mineral composition. SEM images revealed minor smooth spots on eggshells, but these were attributed to natural variability.
population_specificity: Eggs (no human or animal subjects specified).
effective_dosage: RF system operated at 40.68 MHz, 40 W and 16 W (8 min total), and 42 rpm.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the incidence and duration of morbidity symptoms in infants receiving daily eggs, as a secondary outcome of a trial primarily focused on linear growth.
results_summary: The study found that infants receiving one egg daily had a higher incidence of gastrointestinal morbidity (~5% higher) and longer duration of gastrointestinal and respiratory symptoms (1.5 days longer) compared to the control group. The effects were more pronounced when fever was present.
population_specificity: Infants aged 6 to 9 months from a low socioeconomic community in Jouberton, South Africa.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of an ethyl acetate extract of Artemisia ludoviciana on the viability of Fasciola hepatica eggs and adult parasites.
results_summary: The extract demonstrated ovicidal effectiveness ranging from 48% to 92% at concentrations of 100-500 mg/L, with significant damage to egg shells. In adult parasites, fasciolicidal efficiency ranged from 82% to 100%, causing severe tegumentary and organ damage.
population_specificity: Fasciola hepatica eggs and adult parasites.
effective_dosage: 100-500 mg/L for ovicidal assays; 125-500 mg/L for adult parasite assays.
study_duration: 16 hours for ovicidal assays; 24 hours for adult parasite assays.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of egg ladders in accelerating tolerance development in egg-allergic children and to develop a new egg ladder for the German-speaking region.
results_summary: The study found that gradual introduction of highly processed to less processed egg-containing foods can accelerate tolerance development in egg-allergic children. It also highlighted the benefits of home introduction, such as increased food variety and reduced food fears, while recommending inpatient food challenges for severe cases.
population_specificity: Egg-allergic children, particularly those with mild reactions or severe allergic histories.
effective_dosage: Not specified (varies by egg ladder step and processing level).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of anaerobic digestion and electrochemical processes in inactivating helminth (Ascaris suum) eggs in wastewater and faecal sludge.
results_summary: Anaerobic digestion achieved 98% inactivation of A. suum eggs in 35 days, while electrochemical treatment showed 10% inactivation at 940 ppm hypochlorite concentration in 24 hours. The study concluded that inactivation is a combined effect of multiple parameters.
population_specificity: Lab-scale study using spiked A. suum eggs in wastewater and faecal sludge.
effective_dosage: Hypochlorite concentrations of 940, 470, 235, and 156 ppm in electrochemical treatment.
study_duration: 45 days for anaerobic digestion, 24 hours for electrochemical treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a simple and versatile method for monitoring thiamine levels in salmonid eggs to address thiamine deficiency-related reproduction disorders (M74/EMS).
results_summary: The study presented a new extraction and cleanup method for measuring thiamine content in salmonid eggs, which was accurate, precise, and capable of detecting levels below the threshold causing 100% lethality. The method allowed for both quantitative determination of phosphorylated thiamine forms and total thiamine measurement via fluorescence.
population_specificity: Salmonid eggs (specifically in hatcheries in Scandinavia and North America).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of substituting soybean meal with black soldier fly larvae meal on laying performance, egg quality, and metal deposition in eggs, meat, and excreta.
results_summary: Substituting soybean meal with BSF larvae meal increased laying rate and eggshell strength while reducing feed intake. Low transfer of toxic metals (arsenic, lead, cadmium) to eggs was observed, but chromium and iron levels in egg white increased with higher BSF meal inclusion.
population_specificity: 1,008 Lohmann hens (48 weeks old)
effective_dosage: 7%, 14%, and 21% BSF larvae meal replacing soybean meal

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the matrix effect of egg proteins on fluorescence detection of fluoroquinolone residues and establish a pretreatment method to reduce this effect.
results_summary: The study found that egg proteins bind fluoroquinolones, causing signal loss, but trichloroacetic acid treatment effectively reduced the matrix effect to 0.7%, improving detection accuracy.
population_specificity: Egg matrix (not human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different social environments (female-only or mixed-sex groups) affect the duration of rapid yolk deposition in ovarian follicles of hens.
results_summary: Hens exposed to both females and males produced yolks with more rings (indicating longer yolk deposition time) compared to hens in female-only or control groups, but egg count, yolk mass, and yolk diameter did not differ among groups.
population_specificity: Hens (female birds)

study_goal: The study aimed to evaluate the safety of EKGR on the vascular membrane of the egg chorioallantoic membrane and its effects on the skin of male rabbits, not specifically Eggs.
results_summary: The study found that EKGR does not induce irritation in the egg chorioallantoic membrane and causes only mild irritation on rabbit skin without toxic effects.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats and male albino rabbits.
effective_dosage: 200 mg/kg BW EKGR for rabbits; 0.5%, 1%, 2%, and 4% EKGR for rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of phage SP02 as a disinfectant for Salmonella-contaminated breeder eggs and its impact on hatchability, chick health, and intestinal flora.
results_summary: Phage SP02 effectively eliminated Salmonella contamination on eggshells within 12 hours, improved hatching and survival rates, reduced weight loss and tissue Salmonella load in chicks, and decreased Salmonella abundance in the intestinal tract without harming immune organs.
population_specificity: Specific pathogen-free (SPF) breeder eggs and resulting chicks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand why some fecal sediment fails to float after ethyl acetate treatment in the FEA concentration method and to explore methods to improve fecal bulk flotation for better visualization of parasite eggs.
results_summary: The study found that unabsorbed oil droplets in fecal sediment were trapped within leaf structures, and adding acid residues improved fecal bulk float. The interaction of cellulose with ethyl acetate enhanced oil extraction efficacy, aiding in parasite egg visualization.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely fecal samples from clinical practice).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of peracetic acid treatment on parasitic co-infections (Liburna oophaga and Ikanecator primus) in cuttlefish eggs and its impact on hatching rates and embryo survival.
results_summary: The study found that peracetic acid treatment effectively eliminated parasites from cuttlefish eggs, with higher concentrations required for I. primus. Treatment improved embryo survival and hatchling size, demonstrating its potential for controlling parasitic infections in cephalopod culture.
population_specificity: Cuttlefish eggs (Sepia pharaonis species complex) in an aquaculture setting.
effective_dosage: 35 mg/L PAA + 15 mg/L H2O2 for L. oophaga; 70 mg/L PAA + 30 mg/L H2O2 for I. primus.
study_duration: Treatment duration was 10 minutes for L. oophaga; not specified for I. primus beyond achieving elimination.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of bile acids (BAs) supplementation on fatty liver hemorrhagic syndrome (FLHS), production performance, and physiological and quality characteristics of laying hen eggs.
results_summary: BAs supplementation improved egg quality (e.g., albumen height, Haugh unit), regulated lipid metabolism, enhanced antioxidant defenses, reduced inflammation, and modulated gut microbiota in laying hens. The high-fat diet negatively impacted eggshell thickness, weight, and lipid profiles, which were mitigated by BA supplementation.
population_specificity: Sixty Sanhuang laying hens, aged 28 weeks.
effective_dosage: 0.01% and 0.02% of chenodeoxycholic acid (CDCA) or hyodeoxycholic acid (HDCA) in feed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the prevalence of multidrug-resistant bacteria (E. coli, Salmonella spp., and Staphylococcus aureus) in chicken eggs, meat, and feces from poultry farms in Bangladesh.
results_summary: The study found high levels of multidrug-resistant bacteria in eggs, with Salmonella spp. showing 100% resistance to erythromycin and amoxicillin, while E. coli was 100% resistant to erythromycin. However, Salmonella spp. from eggs were fully susceptible to doxycycline, gentamicin, levofloxacin, and tetracycline.
population_specificity: Chicken samples (eggs, meat, feces) from poultry farms in four districts of Bangladesh.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of a combination of electrolyzed reduced water (ERW) and slightly acidic electrolyzed water (SAEW) in removing Salmonella and manure from egg surfaces and its impact on egg quality during storage.
results_summary: ERW was more effective than deionized water and SAEW in removing manure from egg surfaces. The combination of ERW followed by SAEW completely eliminated Salmonella and improved egg quality during storage at 25℃, with less weight loss compared to SAEW alone.
population_specificity: Egg surfaces contaminated with Salmonella and manure.
effective_dosage: Spraying ERW for 10 seconds followed by SAEW for 18 seconds.
study_duration: Not specified (storage at 25℃ was monitored, but intervention duration is unclear).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of genes (DIB, JHE, CAM) in delaying diapause termination in Calliptamus italicus eggs to aid in biological pest control.
results_summary: RNA interference targeting DIB, JHE, and CAM genes significantly reduced their expression and downstream-associated genes, leading to diapause termination but with developmental abnormalities (e.g., smaller head, incomplete yolk absorption). The study suggests these genes as potential targets for biological control.
population_specificity: Calliptamus italicus (grasshopper) eggs

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore public and donor attitudes toward enucleated egg donation for mitochondrial replacement therapy and assisted conception.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the need to understand perspectives on enucleated egg donation but does not report specific findings on its effects. It identifies areas for future research.
population_specificity: General public and egg donors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare vitamin A levels, fatty acid profiles, and gut microbiota in healthy adults consuming carotenoid-enriched eggs versus normal eggs.
results_summary: The study found no significant change in vitamin A levels with carotenoid-enriched eggs but observed significant changes in some fatty acid profiles and gut microbiota compared to normal eggs. Both types of eggs positively influenced dietary habits by reducing saturated fatty acid intake and increasing monounsaturated and polyunsaturated fatty acid intake.
population_specificity: Healthy adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of heat treatment and liming on the viability of Ancylostoma spp. eggs in artificially contaminated sandy soil.
results_summary: Heat treatment at 70 °C and 80 °C destroyed Ancylostoma spp. eggs and prevented larval development. Liming at concentrations of 50%, 30%, and 20% made embryonic development impossible, though filariform larvae retained motility at 20% lime.
population_specificity: Artificially contaminated sandy soil samples.
effective_dosage: Heat treatment at 70 °C and 80 °C; quicklime concentrations of 50%, 30%, 20%, 10%, and 5%.
study_duration: 24 hours for heat treatment; exposure times varied for liming.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify a new parasitic copepod affecting squid eggs and evaluate the efficacy of peracetic acid (PAA) in eliminating the parasite and improving squid embryo survival and hatchling size.
results_summary: The study identified a new parasitic copepod (Ikanecator primus) degrading squid eggshells and demonstrated that a 2-minute immersion in 500 µl/L PAA-product (70 mg/L PAA and 30 mg/L H2O2) eliminated the parasite, improved embryo survival, and increased hatchling size compared to lower concentrations.
population_specificity: Oval squid (Sepioteuthis lessoniana) eggs in aquaculture settings.
effective_dosage: 125 µl/L, 250 µl/L, and 500 µl/L PAA-product (varying PAA and H2O2 concentrations).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of ozone and peroxone in disinfecting drinking water contaminated with Toxocara canis eggs.
results_summary: The study found that the ozone-hydrogen peroxide combination at pH 10 achieved the highest inactivation rate (79.2%) of Toxocara canis eggs. Advanced oxidation processes demonstrated potential as an alternative for water treatment to inactivate these eggs.
population_specificity: Toxocara canis eggs in contaminated water samples.
effective_dosage: Ozone and ozone-hydrogen peroxide combination, exposure times of 60 and 120 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of riboflavin immersion treatment on hatchability, production efficiency, and carcass characteristics of Japanese quail eggs.
results_summary: Riboflavin immersion significantly improved live body weight, feed conversion ratio, hatchability, fertility, blood indices, and carcass traits, with the 5 g/L dose showing the highest returns.
population_specificity: Japanese quail eggs and chicks.
effective_dosage: 3 g/L, 4 g/L, and 5 g/L riboflavin immersion for 2 minutes before incubation.
study_duration: Intervention during egg incubation; effects monitored up to 6 weeks post-hatching.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Schistosoma japonicum eggs could prevent or alleviate symptoms of inflammatory bowel disease by modulating the host immune response and gut microbiota.
results_summary: Intraperitoneal immunization with S. japonicum eggs significantly improved symptoms of DSS-induced acute colitis, including higher body weight and lower inflammatory scores. The eggs also altered gut microbiota composition, increasing beneficial bacteria like Turicibacter and Lactobacillus while reducing harmful bacteria like Odoribacter.
population_specificity: Mice with DSS-induced acute colitis (experimental model).
study_duration: Prior to DSS application (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the molecular mechanisms by which Schistosoma mansoni soluble egg antigens (SEA) drive Th2 immune responses and explore potential targets for modulating these responses.
results_summary: The study found that high-mannose glycans in SEA are critical for activating Dectin-2, ERK signaling, PGE2 synthesis, and Th2 polarization. Inhibition of mPGES-1, but not general COX-1/2, abrogated Th2 induction, highlighting the importance of de novo PGE2 synthesis.
population_specificity: In vitro dendritic cells and immune responses, not human subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the diagnostic performance of the Kato-Katz method for accurately identifying Minute Intestinal Fluke (MIF) and Opisthorchis viverrini (OV) eggs and to assess potential misclassification.
results_summary: The study found that MIF and OV eggs had similar morphology, leading to an average correct classification rate of 61.6%. Accuracy was slightly higher among young parasitologists (66.8%) compared to public health staff (59.0%), but the difference was not significant.
population_specificity: Young parasitologists and public health staff (15 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to present a dataset from the Swedish National Monitoring Programme for Contaminants in Marine Biota (MCoM), including egg samples from three bird species, to track persistent contaminants over time.
results_summary: The study compiled long-term contaminant data (1968-2021) for eggs from common guillemot, common tern, and Eurasian oystercatcher, analyzing over 100 contaminants, but did not report specific effects or safety outcomes related to egg consumption.
population_specificity: Eggs from three bird species (common guillemot, common tern, Eurasian oystercatcher) in the Baltic Sea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of dietary folic acid (FA) on laying hens' production performance, egg quality, and nutritional differences between FA-fortified and ordinary eggs.
results_summary: FA supplementation significantly increased FA content in egg yolks, particularly at 10 mg/kg, and enhanced MUFA and vitamin D levels. Excessive FA reduced amino acid enrichment but did not affect vitamin A, E, or mineral levels.
population_specificity: 288 Hy-Line Brown laying hens (26 weeks old, initial weight 1.65 ± 0.10 kg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of in ovo injection of organic selenium on hatching traits and performance of broiler chickens.
results_summary: In ovo selenium injection reduced hatching rates but improved feed intake, final weight, blood parameters, and carcass components, with no significant effect on immune response or microbial population.
population_specificity: Ross 308 strain broiler chickens (eggs and chicks).
effective_dosage: 2.72 or 5.44 μg of organic selenium per egg, injected once.
study_duration: From injection on the 10th day of incubation through broiler farming parameters.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of daily egg consumption and behavior change communication on linear growth, cognition, and nutritional status in children aged 9-18 months in urban slums.
results_summary: The abstract does not report results as the study is described as a planned randomized controlled trial; findings will be published later.
population_specificity: Children aged 9-18 months in three urban slums in Hyderabad, India, at risk of stunting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of unused surplus frozen eggs from elective egg freezing (EEF) as a donation source for infertile women undergoing IVF treatment and to propose a counseling protocol for prospective donors.
results_summary: The study found that most women who freeze eggs electively do not use them, creating a surplus that could be donated. It proposed a two-step counseling protocol to address motivations and concerns related to donation, such as reciprocity, goodwill, and fears of future contact with donor-conceived offspring.
population_specificity: Women who have undergone elective egg freezing (EEF) for non-medical reasons, categorized into those who have achieved motherhood and those who have given up on motherhood aspirations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of dietary oregano oil supplementation on the shelf life and fatty acid profile of eggs from laying hens.
results_summary: Oregano oil supplementation significantly reduced lipid peroxidation (MDA levels) and altered fatty acid profiles in eggs, increasing beneficial fatty acids like DHA and linolenic acid while decreasing others like palmitic and oleic acid. Storage time also impacted fatty acid composition, with ORE eggs showing a higher n-3:n-6 ratio, which is beneficial for human health.
population_specificity: Laying hens (10 pens of 27 birds each).
study_duration: Eggs were stored for 0, 10, 21, and 35 days; intervention duration for hens not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the sublethal effects of spinosyn on Trichoplusia ni eggs and its parasitoid Trichogramma brassicae, focusing on insecticide resistance mechanisms and parasitoid performance.
results_summary: Sublethal spinosyn treatment on T. ni eggs upregulated genes linked to insecticide resistance in caterpillars, while parasitoids emerging from treated eggs showed increased size, suggesting potential higher performance.
population_specificity: Trichoplusia ni (cruciferous crop pest) eggs and its parasitoid Trichogramma brassicae.
effective_dosage: LC50 for spinosyn A and D on T. ni eggs was 54 ng mL-1.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of using broken egg mixture (BEM) as a nitrogen source in composting for oyster mushroom cultivation and its effects on yield and quality.
results_summary: BEM addition increased nitrogen content in compost and improved crude protein, total amino acids, and essential amino acids in mushrooms. Optimal BEM dosage (P3, initial C/N 26:1) achieved the highest biological efficiency (100.19%) and low contamination (7%), while higher dosages reduced efficiency and increased contamination.
population_specificity: Composting substrate and oyster mushroom cultivation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify key aroma-active compounds in egg yolk products and their formation mechanisms during thermal treatment.
results_summary: The study identified 68 volatile compounds contributing to egg flavor, with boiled and fried eggs relying on distinct sets of compounds. Phosphoethanolamines (PEs) with polyunsaturated fatty acids were found to be primary flavor precursors, participating in lipid oxidation and Maillard reactions.
population_specificity: Egg yolk products (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the pooled prevalence of positive attitudes toward the acceptance of donor eggs, embryos, and sperm in the context of Assisted Reproductive Technology.
results_summary: The study found that the pooled prevalence of positive attitudes toward accepting donor eggs was 38.63%, higher than for donor embryos (33.20%) and sperm (31.34%). Non-Asian countries and infertile men showed higher acceptance rates for donor eggs and embryos, while non-Asian countries and infertile women had higher acceptance for donor sperm.
population_specificity: Infertile men and women, with subgroup analysis focusing on non-Asian countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of low-dose gamma radiation and in ovo feeding with trace elements (Zn, Fe, Cu) on embryonic development and prehatch quality in quail eggs.
results_summary: The study found that eggs injected with 50 mg TEM/egg and exposed to 0.2 Gy gamma radiation (TEM/GR) showed significantly improved hatchability, hatch body weight, organ weight, antioxidant activity, and growth gene expression compared to other groups.
population_specificity: Fertilized quail eggs on the seventh day of incubation.
effective_dosage: 50 mg TES/egg or 50 mg TEM/egg, with gamma radiation at 0 or 0.2 Gy.
study_duration: From the seventh day of incubation until hatching.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of native entomopathogenic fungal isolates in controlling Halyomorpha halys (stink bug) eggs and nymphs as an alternative to chemical insecticides.
results_summary: Beauveria varroae isolate showed the highest toxicity against H. halys eggs and nymphs, significantly reducing egg hatching time (4.5–7.0 days) and nymphal survival (2.1–6.8 days). The study suggests this isolate could be a promising biocontrol agent.
population_specificity: Halyomorpha halys (stink bug) eggs and nymphs (second and fourth instars).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess seasonal variations in the nutrient composition of eggs produced in the highlands of central Guatemala to better inform food composition databases and intervention studies.
results_summary: Most nutrients in eggs showed negligible but statistically significant seasonal differences, with clinically significant fluctuations observed only in vitamins A and E, folate, choline, and calcium. Total energy, protein, trans fatty acids, moisture, and vitamin D3 levels remained consistent between seasons.
population_specificity: Eggs from a local farm in the highlands of central Guatemala.
effective_dosage: Not specified (36 shell eggs collected per season, hard-boiled and pooled for analysis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of cold atmospheric pressure air plasma jet (CAAP-J) treatment on eggshell cuticle quality and Salmonella Enteritidis (SE) inactivation while preserving egg quality.
results_summary: The study found that CAAP-J treatment at 800 W for 120 s effectively inactivated SE without altering egg quality, as confirmed by various measurements (pH, yolk color, HU, and eggshell strength). No viable SE cells were detected post-treatment, and the eggshell cuticle remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Shell eggs inoculated with SE (7 log10 cfu/egg).
effective_dosage: 800 W for 120 s at a fixed distance of 20 mm and an air flow rate of 3600 L/h.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a gas-phase hydroxyl-radical process for decontaminating hatchery and table eggs to reduce Salmonella contamination without affecting egg quality.
results_summary: The hydroxyl-radical treatment achieved a >5 log CFU/egg reduction of Salmonella, maintained egg quality metrics over a 35-day shelf-life, and did not negatively impact hatchery rates or egg cuticle integrity. In comparison, traditional egg washing only achieved a 2.76 log CFU/egg reduction.
population_specificity: Fertilized eggs (n=61) and table eggs.
effective_dosage: 2% v/v H2O2 delivered at 30 mL/min with a UV-C dose of 19 mJ/cm2 and ozone (20 ppm) for 10s.
study_duration: 10-second treatment, with quality assessed over 35 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how shell breakage and calcium carbonate addition affect the shell repair rate, food intake, egg production, shell strength, and calcium content in Pomacea canaliculata snails.
results_summary: Shell breakage combined with calcium carbonate addition significantly increased egg diameter compared to control groups, with faster shell repair rates in female snails. No significant differences were observed in shell strength or calcium content for male snails.
population_specificity: Pomacea canaliculata snails (aquatic invasive species).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of dichromatic light (green-red) at different intensities during incubation on hatching traits and post-hatch performance of Japanese quail.
results_summary: Hatchability improved with dichromatic light (150, 250, and 350 lx) compared to complete darkness. The 250 lx group showed the best growth performance (weight gain, feed intake, feed conversion ratio, and livability) and lower early embryonic mortality. Serum chemistry values were higher in the dark group, while pre-slaughter and carcass weights were better in the 250 and 350 lx groups.
population_specificity: Japanese quail eggs and chicks.
effective_dosage: Dichromatic light (green-red) at 150, 250, and 350 lx with a 12L:12D lighting schedule.
study_duration: Duration of incubation and post-hatch performance period (specific length not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antiviral effect of hyoscyamine against Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) and its immunomodulatory activity in embryonated chicken eggs.
results_summary: Pretreatment with hyoscyamine sulphate significantly reduced viral load in chorioallantoic membrane (CAM) and brain tissues, upregulated immune-related genes (TLR3, TLR7, TLR8, IL-4, IL-10, interferons), and downregulated TLR4. In silico studies suggested stable binding between hyoscyamine and JEV NS5 protein.
population_specificity: Embryonated chicken eggs

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether excretory/secretory products from Schistosoma japonicum eggs (ESP-SJE) could protect against allergic airway inflammation in a murine asthma model.
results_summary: ESP-SJE treatment significantly reduced inflammatory cell infiltration (especially eosinophils), lowered total and OVA-specific IgE levels, suppressed Th2-type cytokines (IL-4), and upregulated regulatory T cells (Tregs) in lung tissue. Nine potential therapeutic proteins in ESP-SJE were identified, suggesting a mechanism for its anti-inflammatory effects.
population_specificity: Mice with OVA-induced allergic airway inflammation
effective_dosage: Administered intraperitoneally on days -1, 13, 20, and days 21-24 (exact dosage not specified)
study_duration: Intervention spanned from pre-sensitization (day -1) through the challenge phase (days 21-24)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different egg cooling rates after oviposition affect blastoderm development, embryonic mortality, hatchability, and hatch time in broiler hatching eggs from young and old breeder flocks.
results_summary: Rapid cooling retarded blastoderm development and delayed hatch time. It reduced hatchability in young flock eggs due to higher embryonic mortality but improved hatchability in old flock eggs by lowering early embryonic mortality.
population_specificity: Commercial Ross 308 broiler breeder eggs from young (28 wk) and old (64 wk) flocks.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (egg cooling profiles: 24°C within 6 h vs. 45 min).
study_duration: Eggs stored for 6 days at 16°C and 75% relative humidity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop assisted reproductive technologies for gamete collection, artificial fertilization, and captive-rearing of embryos in Alytes obstetricans.
results_summary: Sperm collection was achieved with hCG, but only 17-50% of males responded. Artificial fertilization resulted in 10% of eggs showing complete embryo development. Separating eggs individually improved embryo survival (27-61%) compared to keeping them together (only one sub-clutch had 36% survival).
population_specificity: Alytes obstetricans (a species of frog)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report clinical signs, therapeutic strategies, and findings related to airsacculitis and the presence of Diplotriaenoidea superfamily eggs in a tropical screech owl.
results_summary: The study found eggs of the Diplotriaenoidea superfamily in the owl's feces and identified bacterial airsacculitis caused by Escherichia coli, Klebsiella pneumoniae, and Enterobacter aerogenes. Despite treatment, the owl died, with necropsy revealing undigested food, intestinal gas, and thickened air sacs.
population_specificity: A tropical screech owl nestling (Megascops choliba) in the Amazon biome.
effective_dosage: Not specified for eggs (only medication dosages mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether polysaccharides from sea urchin eggs (SEP) could improve inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) by regulating autophagy in intestinal epithelial cells via the CD36-PI3K/Akt pathway.
results_summary: SEP reduced ulcerative colitis symptoms in mice, including inflammation, gut barrier repair, and improved intestinal flora. It also modulated autophagy-related factors and the PI3K/Akt pathway in intestinal epithelial cells.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice with dextran sodium sulfate-induced ulcerative colitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the lethal and sublethal effects of tebufenozide on Chrysoperla carnea (a predator insect) to assess its compatibility with integrated pest management (IPM) strategies.
results_summary: Tebufenozide showed low toxicity to C. carnea, with no adverse effects on egg hatching, neonate survival, or adult fecundity. However, it reduced larval and pupal development times and influenced prey preference in third-instar larvae.
population_specificity: Chrysoperla carnea (a generalist predator insect) under laboratory conditions.
effective_dosage: 0.75 mL/L (for prey treatment) and recommended field dose (for adult ingestion).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of tartaric and salicylic acids on the chemical composition of eggs produced by Lohman chickens raised at high temperatures.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of tartaric and salicylic acids on the moisture, protein, fat, carbohydrates, or ash content of egg whites and yolks. The treatments did not significantly alter the quality of the eggs.
population_specificity: 210 brown Lohman strain laying hens raised at high temperatures.
effective_dosage: 0.2% tartaric acid, 0.2% salicylic acid, or 0.4% mixture in drinking water or feed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of freshwater treatment on salmon louse egg strings, including structural changes, hatching success, and molecular responses.
results_summary: A 3-hour freshwater treatment caused structural collapse of egg strings and prevented hatching, while shorter treatments or brackish water had milder effects. Embryos showed altered gene expression in low salinity and delayed hatching compared to seawater controls.
population_specificity: Salmon louse (Lepeophtheirus salmonis) egg strings
effective_dosage: 3-hour freshwater treatment (shorter treatments and brackish water also tested)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the biological parameters of diapaused and non-diapaused Anastatus japonicus when stored long-term in Antheraea pernyi eggs to assess mass production feasibility.
results_summary: Diapaused larvae showed better cold tolerance and enhanced lifespan, fecundity, and oviposition period after 6 months of refrigeration, but these benefits sharply declined after 12 months. No differences in progeny sex ratio were observed between diapaused and non-diapaused groups.
population_specificity: Anastatus japonicus (a parasitoid wasp) reared on Antheraea pernyi eggs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of granular particles in the perivitelline space on oocyte maturation and fertilization outcomes during in vitro fertilization.
results_summary: The study found that an exceptional presence of granular particles in the perivitelline space affected fertilization rates but not blastocyst quality, resulting in a successful twin live birth after embryo transfer.
population_specificity: A 30-year-old woman with no previous pregnancy undergoing her first in vitro fertilization treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the ovicidal activities of camel milk and its fractions (CMW, CMC, SCM) against Fasciola gigantica eggs.
results_summary: Camel milk fractions, particularly CMW and CMC, showed high ovicidal activity (97.58% and 96.9%, respectively) at 1% concentration after 15 days, outperforming the positive control (Nitroxynil). The egg hatching ratios were significantly lower for CMW (1.67%) and CMC (2.33%) compared to the negative control (70.17%).
population_specificity: Fasciola gigantica eggs (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: 0.5% and 1% concentrations of camel milk fractions (CMW, CMC, SCM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the positive rates for Enterobius vermicularis eggs among preschool children in Yeosu-si, Korea, over a 5-year period and assess the effectiveness of a test-treatment strategy.
results_summary: The study found annual positive rates for E. vermicularis eggs declined from 5.0% in 2017 to 1.0% in 2021, with higher rates in boys and children aged 5-7 years. The results suggest that continuous intervention centered around test-treatment can significantly reduce infection rates.
population_specificity: Preschool children (0-7 years) in Yeosu-si, Korea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of egg storage duration and short incubation period during storage (SPIDES) on embryo mortality, hatchability, hatching time, and chick quality in broiler breeder eggs.
results_summary: Shorter storage (5 days) and SPIDES treatment significantly reduced embryo mortality, improved hatchability, shortened hatching time, and enhanced chick quality compared to longer storage periods and control groups.
population_specificity: Broiler breeder eggs (ROSS 308)
effective_dosage: SPIDES treatment involved raising egg shell temperature to 100 °F for 3.5 hours.
study_duration: Storage durations tested were 5, 10, and 15 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the digestive characteristics and anti-tumor mechanisms of preserved eggs using an in vitro dynamic human gastrointestinal model.
results_summary: Preserved egg digests showed high protein and fat digestibility (90% and 87%, respectively), significantly increased free radical scavenging activity, and inhibited the growth, cloning, and migration of HepG2 cells while inducing apoptosis via mitochondrial pathways.
population_specificity: In vitro study using HepG2 cells (human liver cancer cell line).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Trans-cinnamaldehyde nanoemulsions (TCNE) as an antimicrobial wash to reduce Salmonella Enteritidis contamination on shelled eggs.
results_summary: TCNE treatments (0.06-0.48%) effectively inactivated S. Enteritidis by 2-2.5 log cfu/egg within 1 minute, even in the presence of organic matter, and inhibited trans-shell migration of the pathogen without affecting shell color.
population_specificity: Shelled eggs contaminated with S. Enteritidis.
study_duration: Immediate effects assessed at 1 minute; shell color evaluated over 14 days of refrigerated storage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether stress-related physiological responses in American robins differ when exposed to mimetic (host-like) versus non-mimetic (parasite-like) eggs.
results_summary: The study found no effect of egg type on heart rate or plasma corticosterone levels, but non-mimetic eggs upregulated POMC gene expression in the pituitary, suggesting a potential stress-related response.
population_specificity: Incubating female American robins (Turdus migratorius).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (egg exposure was experimental, not a dosage).
study_duration: Immediate (heart rate) and 2 hours (corticosterone and POMC measurements) post-exposure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether enriching eggs with n-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids, selenium, vitamin E, and lutein could significantly increase their nutritional content compared to conventional eggs.
results_summary: Enriched eggs showed significantly higher levels of n-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids, selenium, vitamin E, and lutein compared to conventional eggs, with increases ranging from 1.18 to 8.94 times depending on the nutrient.
population_specificity: 100 TETRA SL laying hens divided into control and experimental groups.
effective_dosage: Experimental group received 1.5% fish oil + 1.5% rapeseed oil + 2.0% linseed oil, 0.47 mg/kg organic selenium, 125.2 mg/kg vitamin E, and 120.5 mg/kg lutein.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different selenium forms (sodium selenite, yeast selenium, methionine selenium) and levels (0.15 mg/kg and 0.30 mg/kg) on laying hens' productivity, egg quality, selenium content, antioxidant capacity, immunity, and selenoprotein expression.
results_summary: Methionine selenium (SM) increased laying rate and improved egg quality, preservation, and selenium deposition compared to inorganic selenium (SS). Organic selenium (SY and SM) enhanced antioxidant capacity and immune functions at 0.15 mg Se/kg, with SM showing stronger selenoprotein expression.
population_specificity: 576 forty-three-week-old Hyland Brown laying hens
effective_dosage: 0.15 mg Se/kg and 0.30 mg Se/kg of SS, SY, and SM

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether fish oil, as an antioxidant supplement, could mitigate adverse health effects of traffic-related air pollution (TRAP).
results_summary: The study found conflicting evidence regarding the efficacy of fish oil supplements in mitigating TRAP-related health effects, with no clear consensus on its effectiveness.
population_specificity: Human subjects, including potentially susceptible populations like children, the elderly, asthmatics, and occupational workers exposed to TRAP.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether fish-oil supplementation could protect skin against inflammation and oxidative stress caused by exposure to fine particulate matter (PM).
results_summary: The study suggested that fish-oil supplementation improved biomarkers of skin inflammation and oxidative stress in response to short-term PM exposure.
population_specificity: 65 healthy young adults in Shanghai, China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether maternal dietary interventions with fish oil and high-dose vitamin D during pregnancy could reduce asthma and wheeze in offspring by influencing microbial effects.
results_summary: The study found that the dietary interventions altered infant airway microbiota and immune mediator profiles but did not affect infant fecal or maternal vaginal microbiota. The changed airway microbiota was a minor and non-significant mediator of the protective effect on asthma risk.
population_specificity: 695 pregnant women and their children.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the potential health effects of consuming cod residual protein powder, particularly its impact on glucose metabolism and related biomarkers.
results_summary: Cod residual protein supplementation reduced plasma concentrations of α-hydroxybutyrate, β-hydroxybutyrate, and acetoacetate, suggesting potential glucoregulatory benefits, but increased trimethylamine N-oxide levels in plasma and urine. Fasting glucose and insulin levels remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Lean adults (n=40 completed the study).
effective_dosage: 8.1 g/day of cod residual protein (Cod-RP) in capsule form.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of fish oil supplementation on glucose control and lipid levels in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation did not significantly improve glucose control outcomes (FPG, FINS, HbA1c, HOMA-IR) but was associated with favorable changes in lipid levels, including reduced triglycerides and increased HDL cholesterol, particularly in Asian and low-dose subgroups.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
effective_dosage: Low-dose (<2 g/d n-3 PUFA) and other unspecified dosages.
study_duration: Varied (mid and long duration showed effects, short duration did not).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare compliance, acceptability, and effects on nutritional status and side effects between fish-oil capsules and a nutritional drink with equivalent n-3 LC PUFA doses in chemotherapy patients with GI tract cancers.
results_summary: Capsules showed better compliance (96.4%) than the drink (80.8%), but no differences were found in nutritional status, side effects, or blood n-3 LC PUFA levels. Capsule intake correlated with reduced nausea.
population_specificity: 41 patients with advanced GI tract cancers receiving chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: 10 capsules/day or 400 mL/day of nutritional drink, both providing equivalent n-3 LC PUFA doses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effects of fish oil supplementation on athletes' physiology, health, and performance, assess evidence quality, document side effects, and discuss risks and future research needs.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation showed consistent positive effects on reaction time, mood, cardiovascular dynamics in cyclists, muscle recovery, TNF-α levels, and postexercise NO responses, but no clear benefits for endurance performance, lung function, muscle force, or training adaptation. Few negative outcomes were reported.
population_specificity: Athletes ranging from recreational to elite, including Olympic and professional sports, with a mean age of 24.9 ± 4.5 years (70% male).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether omega-3 PUFA (fish oil) combined with low-dose aspirin, as an adjunct to periodontal debridement, improves clinical and immunological outcomes in periodontitis patients with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that omega-3 PUFA and aspirin supplementation, particularly when administered after periodontal debridement, led to significant clinical improvements (e.g., reduced probing depth, attachment gain) and decreased inflammatory cytokine levels (IFN-γ, IL-8, IL-6) in diabetic patients with periodontitis.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes and periodontitis (n=75, 25/group).
effective_dosage: 3 g of fish oil/day + 100 mg aspirin/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether marine omega-3 fatty acid (n-3 FA) supplementation could prevent cardiovascular disease (CVD) in general populations at usual risk.
results_summary: The study reviewed results from the VITAL trial, discussing mechanistic studies and summarizing meta-analyses, but specific efficacy outcomes for n-3 FAs in preventing CVD were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: General populations at usual risk for cardiovascular disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of fish oil supplement on psoriasis severity.
results_summary: Fish oil supplement did not significantly reduce psoriasis severity as measured by the Psoriasis Area and Severity Index score. The meta-analysis of three RCTs showed no meaningful treatment effect.
population_specificity: 625 participants across 13 RCTs, focusing on individuals with psoriasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin D and marine ω-3 fatty acid (n-3 FA) supplementation reduces systemic inflammation biomarkers in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that neither vitamin D nor n-3 FA supplementation over one year significantly reduced inflammation biomarkers (IL-6, TNFR2, hsCRP).
population_specificity: Women ≥55 and men ≥50 years of age.

study_goal: To test the safety and potential lipid-lowering effects of LCMUFA-rich saury fish oil supplementation in healthy normolipidemic adults.
results_summary: Saury oil supplementation was safe, reduced LDL particle counts by 12%, increased HDL particle size slightly, and improved other cardiovascular parameters like plasma TG levels and cholesterol efflux capacity compared to control oil.
population_specificity: 30 healthy normolipidemic adults with BMI <25 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if long-term fish oil supplementation reduces the risk of mobility disability and enhances the benefits of physical activity in older adults.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation was associated with a lower risk of major mobility disability (HR, 0.78) but did not enhance the benefits of physical activity on mobility outcomes. Changes in physical performance were not influenced by fish oil supplementation.
population_specificity: Sedentary adults aged 70 to 89 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of riboflavin supplementation on oxidative stress, inflammation, clinical symptoms, and the faecal microbiome in patients with Crohn's disease.
results_summary: Riboflavin supplementation reduced systemic oxidative stress, showed mixed anti-inflammatory effects, and decreased clinical symptoms (HBI). FISH analysis indicated reduced Enterobacteriaceae in patients with low faecal calprotectin levels, though MGS analysis did not confirm microbiome changes.
population_specificity: 70 patients with Crohn's disease of varying disease activity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the current understanding of the effects and mechanisms of ω-3 PUFAs from fish oil on autoimmune diseases.
results_summary: The study found that while epidemiological evidence supports the benefits of ω-3 PUFAs, clinical trials have produced mixed results. Recent genetic and clinical studies suggest potential benefits in preventing and treating autoimmune diseases like rheumatoid arthritis and lupus.
population_specificity: Human studies and genetic mouse models (no specific human population detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a locally produced, fish-based ready-to-use supplementary food (RUSF) could prevent growth faltering in Cambodian infants compared to other supplements or no intervention.
results_summary: The fish-based RUSF did not significantly differ from the control group in weight-for-age (WAZ) or height-for-age (HAZ) z-scores but showed a small increase in mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC). Low consumers of RUSF had modest improvements in WAZ, weight-for-height (WHZ), and MUAC compared to the control, though the clinical significance was limited.
population_specificity: Cambodian infants aged 6 to 11 months (n=485).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of omega-3 supplementation (from fish oil) on erythrocyte lipid species, including sphingomyelin and phosphatidylethanolamine concentrations, in individuals at ultra-high risk of psychosis.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation significantly increased the n-3 index and n-3 LCPUFA incorporation into erythrocytes while reducing n-6 LCPUFA species. It also appeared to prevent the increase in certain sphingomyelin species observed in the placebo group.
population_specificity: Individuals at ultra-high risk of psychosis
effective_dosage: 840 mg EPA and 560 mg DHA per day

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if fish oil supplementation (providing EPA and DHA) improved neuropsychological performance and brain morphology in healthy adults with low baseline omega-3 fatty acid intake.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation did not improve performance in any cognitive domain or alter brain morphology, except for a modest improvement in executive function in participants with very low baseline DHA levels.
population_specificity: 271 healthy mid-life adults (30-54 years, 118 men, 153 women) consuming ≤300 mg/day of LCn-3FAs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fish-oil supplementation could mitigate systemic oxidative stress caused by acute O₃ exposure in young adults.
results_summary: The study found that fish-oil supplementation significantly reduced oxidative stress biomarkers compared to placebo, suggesting it may alleviate O₃-induced oxidative stress.
population_specificity: 65 young adults in Shanghai, China.
study_duration: Last two months of treatments (exact total duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a cod protein hydrolysate (CPH) supplement on symptom severity, gut integrity markers, and fecal fermentation in patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study investigated the impact of CPH on IBS symptoms and gut health markers.
population_specificity: Patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether marine omega-3 supplementation reduces the risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) by analyzing outcomes like myocardial infarction, CHD death, and stroke.
results_summary: Marine omega-3 supplementation was associated with a significantly lower risk of myocardial infarction (RR 0.92 [0.86, 0.99]) when excluding the REDUCE-IT trial, but other CVD outcomes showed mixed or non-significant results.
population_specificity: Participants in 13 trials, with documented CVD events (e.g., myocardial infarctions, strokes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to critically evaluate the known effects of fish oil, including its benefits and controversies, to determine its impact on human health.
results_summary: The study found contradictory evidence regarding the positive effects of fish oil on human health, making it difficult to draw definitive conclusions about its benefits. The abstract highlights the lack of standardized testing approaches and varying baselines in nutritional and lifestyle habits across populations.
population_specificity: General human population (not specified further)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether maternal supplementation with n-3 long-chain polyunsaturated fatty acids (from fish oil) reduces the incidence of early preterm delivery or prolongs gestation beyond term.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in early preterm delivery rates between the n-3 and control groups. Infants in the n-3 group were more likely to be very large for gestational age, but no other significant differences in pregnancy or neonatal outcomes were observed. Minor gastrointestinal disturbances were more common in the n-3 group.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with single or multiple fetuses, starting supplementation before 20 weeks of gestation.
effective_dosage: 900 mg of n-3 long-chain polyunsaturated fatty acids daily.
study_duration: From before 20 weeks of gestation until 34 weeks of gestation or delivery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of two different doses of long-chain n-3 PUFAs (from fish oil) on gestation duration in pregnant women.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in hazard rates for preterm delivery or mean gestation duration between the fish oil and control groups, though a potential delay in delivery (5-10 days) was observed in low fish consumers. The trial lacked statistical power to confirm fish oil's efficacy in preventing preterm birth.
population_specificity: Unselected pregnant women in China with varying habitual fish intake (low and higher).
effective_dosage: High fish oil (HFO) group: 2.0 g/d LC n-3 PUFAs; low fish oil (LFO) group: 0.5 g/d LC n-3 PUFAs; control group: 0 g/d.
study_duration: From midgestation until the last day of the preterm period (<259 days of gestation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic role of long-chain n-3 PUFA from fish oil in ageing, particularly its effects on sarcopenia and cardio-metabolic health.
results_summary: The study found that n-3 PUFA supplementation potentiates muscle protein synthesis in response to amino acids or exercise in older adults, leading to improvements in muscle mass and strength. It also suggests n-3 PUFA may benefit cardio-metabolic health by regulating blood glucose homeostasis.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether fish oil supplementation improves anti-cancer treatment response, performance status, and reduces adverse events in gastrointestinal cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation led to better performance status and less severe diarrhea compared to placebo, but no differences were observed in treatment response, adverse events, or oxidative stress parameters.
population_specificity: Gastrointestinal cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: Two capsules of fish oil containing 1.55 g of EPA + DHA daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a single dose of fish protein hydrolysate (FPH) could improve endothelium-dependent dilation in healthy adults compared to whey protein hydrolysate (WPH) and placebo.
results_summary: The study found that WPH significantly improved endothelium-dependent dilation at 30 minutes, while FPH did not. However, FPH had a significantly higher total antioxidant capacity than WPH.
population_specificity: Nine healthy adults.
study_duration: Acute (effects measured up to 120 minutes post-supplementation).

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine whether dietary fish-oil supplementation (omega-3 fatty acids) protects cardiovascular health against fine particulate matter (PM2.5) exposure.
