results_summary: The study found that omega-3 fatty acid supplementation was associated with short-term subclinical cardiovascular benefits against PM2.5 exposure, including reduced oxidative stress and inflammation biomarkers.
population_specificity: 65 healthy college students in Shanghai, China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of rumen-protected fish oil supplementation on meat quality and sensory attributes in Angus heifers compared to sunflower oil.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation slightly affected meat quality and oxidative shelf life but had minimal impact on sensory attributes, with only faint off-flavors detected. Differences between muscles were more significant than between diets.
population_specificity: Angus heifers
effective_dosage: 450 g/day of rumen-protected fish oil (60 g/kg total intake)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of arginine, glutamine, and fish oil supplementation in reducing toxicities and improving adherence to concurrent chemoradiotherapy (CCRT) in cancer patients.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation, combined with arginine and glutamine, significantly reduced severe hematologic toxicities (5% vs. 23%) and improved CCRT completion rates (91% vs. 75%) compared to a regular diet alone, though survival differences were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: 88 cancer patients (45% head and neck, 32% esophageal, 23% cervical) undergoing CCRT.
study_duration: Duration of CCRT course (exact length not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the acute effects of a single dose of cholecalciferol (Vitamin D) in relation to fish consumption and its potential impact on cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factors.
results_summary: The study suggests that fish peptide consumption may lower CVD risk factors and highlights an association between 25-hydroxyvitamin D deficiency and CVD, including conditions like diabetes. However, specific outcomes of the acute cholecalciferol intervention are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of n-3 PUFA (omega-3 fatty acids, commonly found in fish) intake on cardiovascular and kidney-related outcomes in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: The study found that n-3 PUFA supplementation may reduce cardiovascular mortality in hemodialysis patients and prevent end-stage kidney disease (ESKD) in CKD patients not on renal replacement therapy, but it showed little or no effect on all-cause mortality, acute transplant rejection, or allograft loss. The safety profile was uncertain, with no clear increase in bleeding or gastrointestinal side-effects.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD), including those on hemodialysis and those not receiving renal replacement therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether omega-3 PUFA supplementation from fish oil reduces liver fat and improves metabolic markers in overweight men.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of fish oil supplementation on liver fat, liver enzymes, anthropometry, or body composition, including visceral adipose tissue, compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Overweight men (BMI 25.0–29.9 kg/m²; waist > 94 cm) without apparent health issues.
effective_dosage: 1728 mg marine triglycerides daily (588 mg EPA, 412 mg DHA, plus 200 mg coenzyme Q10).

study_goal: The researchers were summarizing evidence on treatments and prevention for atopic eczema, not specifically evaluating Fish.
results_summary: The abstract does not mention Fish or its effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus was on atopic eczema treatments).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine whether fish oil or omega-3 fatty acids could modulate inflammation and potentially reduce the risk of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) in preterm infants.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that fish oil supplementation has the potential to alter the inflammatory response and may reduce the risk of NEC, but it does not provide specific results or data.
population_specificity: Preterm infants at risk for necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of fish oil supplementation as a nutritional strategy for managing psoriasis.
results_summary: The study found that omega-3 supplements (fish oil) were proven beneficial for psoriasis patients, though specific effect sizes or statistical significance were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with psoriasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether omega-3 fatty acid supplementation could attenuate muscle disuse atrophy and influence muscle size, mass, and protein synthesis rates in women.
results_summary: The study found that omega-3 fatty acid supplementation enhanced muscle protein synthesis and muscle size, but its effect on attenuating muscle disuse atrophy was not conclusively determined.
population_specificity: Twenty women with an average BMI of 23.0 ± 2.3 kg/m².
study_duration: 2 weeks of muscle disuse and recovery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the Hp phenotype influences weight loss and metabolic improvements in response to calorie-restricted diets with or without fish oil supplementation.
results_summary: The study found that obese women with the Hp 1-1 phenotype showed greater reductions in waist circumference, body fat, and insulin resistance compared to other Hp phenotypes when following calorie-restricted diets, with additional benefits observed in those receiving fish oil supplementation.
population_specificity: Abdominally obese Taiwanese women with ≥2 metabolic components.
effective_dosage: Not specified (fish oil supplementation details not provided in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of omega-3 PUFA supplementation in improving athlete performance, focusing on muscle adaptation, energy metabolism, recovery, and injury prevention.
results_summary: The study found that omega-3 PUFA supplementation may improve endurance capacity by reducing oxygen cost and promote recovery from muscle-damaging exercise, but there is insufficient evidence to support benefits for muscle growth during resistance training or muscle preservation during catabolic scenarios.
population_specificity: Athletes in strength/power-, endurance-, and team-based sports.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fish oil-enriched enteral nutrition improves clinical outcomes in critically ill adult patients in ICUs.
results_summary: The study found no significant effects of fish oil supplementation on 28-day, ICU, or hospital mortality, but it did observe reduced ICU length of stay and ventilation duration, particularly in patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome. However, these benefits were primarily noted in low-quality trials, and no significant effects were seen on hospital length of stay or infectious complications.
population_specificity: Critically ill adult patients in intensive care units (ICUs), with a subgroup analysis focusing on patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate associations between serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25OHD) concentrations and lifestyle factors, including dietary intake (such as fish) and supplement use in older Europeans.
results_summary: Higher 25OHD concentrations were associated with dietary vitamin D, supplement use (fish liver oil, omega-3), and oily fish intake. Vitamin D deficiency and insufficiency were prevalent in the studied population.
population_specificity: Men and women aged ≥65 years from seven centers across Europe.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of n-3 LCPUFA supplementation during pregnancy on pregnancy duration, birth weight, and size for gestational age.
results_summary: n-3 LCPUFA supplementation was associated with a 2-day prolongation of pregnancy, a 97-g higher birth weight, and increased size for gestational age compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 736 pregnant women and their offspring from the Copenhagen Prospective Studies on Asthma in Childhood 2010 cohort, excluding those with certain disorders or high vitamin D intake.
study_duration: From weeks 22-26 of pregnancy until 1 week after birth

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether maternal supplementation with ω-3 LCPUFA during pregnancy reduces the risk of obesity in offspring.
results_summary: The study found no association between prenatal ω-3 LCPUFA supplementation and obesity measures in offspring. High heterogeneity, small sample sizes, and attrition rates made long-term effects unclear.
population_specificity: Pregnant women and their offspring.
study_duration: Minimum 1-month follow-up post-partum (intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a DHA-rich fish oil supplement on cerebrovascular function, mood, and cognitive performance in borderline hypertensive individuals with low habitual omega-3 intake.
results_summary: The study found a 26% increase in cerebrovascular responsiveness (CVR) to hypercapnia after 20 weeks of supplementation, suggesting improved cerebral perfusion. No other specific outcomes (mood or cognitive performance) were detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Borderline hypertensives aged 40–85 years with low habitual LCn-3PUFA intake.
effective_dosage: 1600 mg DHA + 400 mg EPA daily (four capsules/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of omega-3 LCPUFA (from fish or supplements) during pregnancy on maternal, perinatal, and neonatal outcomes, as well as longer-term outcomes for mother and child.
results_summary: Omega-3 LCPUFA reduced preterm birth and early preterm birth, possibly lowered perinatal death and neonatal care admissions, and decreased low birthweight, though it may slightly increase large-for-gestational age babies. Maternal outcomes showed mixed or insufficient evidence, while child/adult outcomes showed little to no difference in neurodevelopment or growth.
population_specificity: Pregnant women (19,927 participants) at low, mixed, or high risk of poor pregnancy outcomes, primarily from upper-middle or high-income countries.
study_duration: Duration of pregnancy (intervention timing varied by study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine how maternal BMI affects the association between omega-6 to omega-3 fatty acid ratios and neonatal outcomes, focusing on fetal growth and perinatal health.
results_summary: A higher maternal omega-6 to omega-3 fatty acid ratio was associated with impaired fetal growth, shorter gestation, higher incidence of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, and longer neonatal hospital stays in overweight/obese women, but not in lean women.
population_specificity: Pregnant women (16-22 weeks gestation) categorized as lean (BMI 18.5-24.9 kg/m²) or overweight/obese (BMI ≥25.0 kg/m²).
study_duration: From 16-22 weeks of pregnancy until delivery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of fish oil supplementation (n-3 PUFA) on inflammation and clinical outcomes in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) patients.
results_summary: The study found that n-3 PUFA supplementation may reduce inflammation and provide clinical benefits, potentially delaying the need for pharmacotherapy. However, methodological limitations in existing studies restrict robust conclusions.
population_specificity: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) patients

study_goal: To examine the effect of n-3 LCPUFA (fish oil) supplementation during pregnancy on offspring anthropometry and body composition.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation from pregnancy week 24 led to higher BMI, weight/height, and waist circumference in offspring aged 0-6 years, but not increased obesity risk. Body composition showed proportional increases in lean, bone, and fat mass, suggesting a general growth-stimulating effect.
population_specificity: 736 pregnant women and their offspring in the Copenhagen Prospective Studies on Asthma in Childhood.
study_duration: From pregnancy week 24 until one week after birth.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of fish oil supplementation in preventing sudden cardiac death (SCD) and all-cause mortality in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).
results_summary: The study found unclear evidence of effectiveness for omega-3 fatty acids (fish oil) in preventing SCD and all-cause mortality, with no significant reduction observed.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the historical use of fish oil (FO) for cardiovascular and inflammatory conditions, assess conflicting evidence on its benefits, and explore the role of specialized pro-resolving mediators (SPMs) as a potential mechanism of action.
results_summary: The abstract notes that meta-analyses of large RCTs found no cardiovascular benefit from FO, but later research identified SPMs as bioactive components that may resolve inflammation, suggesting potential therapeutic applications in various inflammatory diseases.
population_specificity: Individuals with cardiovascular disease, inflammatory conditions, and specific diseases like PICS, inflammatory bowel disease, sepsis, pancreatitis, and ARDS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of increasing dietary lipid levels on growth, nutrient utilization, body composition, tissue fatty acid composition, and Δ6 fad gene expression in silver barb.
results_summary: The study tested five diets with varying fish oil levels (0-120 g/kg) and measured outcomes related to growth and nutrient utilization, though specific results are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Silver barb (Puntius gonionotus) with an initial body weight of 11.3 ± 0.23 g.
effective_dosage: 0, 30, 60, 90, and 120 g fish oil per kg of feed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of fish proteins in a comprehensive, individualized diet for colorectal cancer (CRC) patients as part of integrative treatment.
results_summary: The study found that a diet emphasizing fish proteins, along with plant proteins and healthful fats, is supported by substantial evidence from cohort studies for CRC patients. High glycemic diets and refined carbohydrates should be avoided.
population_specificity: Colorectal cancer (CRC) patients undergoing integrative treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fish oil supplementation, combined with a calorie-restricted diet, improves serum iron status in overweight and obese adults, particularly through reductions in IL-6 or weight loss.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation did not enhance weight or fat loss but preserved lean body mass. A significant improvement in iron status was observed only in participants with a moderate reduction in serum IL-6 who took fish oil, while modest weight loss alone did not affect iron status.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese Taiwanese adults with at least two metabolic components.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of oily fish as a source of vitamin D during pregnancy and its association with pregnancy outcomes.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that oily fish is a significant source of vitamin D for pregnant women, and adequate vitamin D levels may reduce risks of adverse pregnancy outcomes like preeclampsia, gestational diabetes, and preterm labor. However, the study does not isolate fish consumption effects from other vitamin D sources.
population_specificity: Pregnant women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the association between fish consumption and vitamin D status in Polish preadolescents.
results_summary: The study found an association between higher 25-OHD concentrations and regular fish consumption, indicating a positive effect on vitamin D levels. Seasonal variations showed significant improvement in vitamin D status from winter to summer.
population_specificity: 720 healthy Polish children aged 9-13 years (409 girls, 311 boys).
study_duration: Measurements were taken twice, in March (post-winter) and October (post-summer).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fish oil supplementation could modulate inflammation and immunosenescence in older HIV-infected adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in inflammatory cytokine production or markers of immunosenescence between the fish oil and placebo groups after 12 weeks of supplementation. Fish oil did not demonstrate favorable effects on inflammation or immune senescence in this population.
population_specificity: Clinically stable HIV-infected adults aged 40-70 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review evidence on the cardiovascular benefits of seafood-derived n-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids and support their inclusion in dietary recommendations.
results_summary: The study found that seafood long-chain n-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids have beneficial effects on cardiovascular disease, supported by observational, experimental, and randomized controlled trials. Potential mechanisms include antiarrhythmic, anti-inflammatory, hematologic, and endothelial effects, though longer-term dietary trials are needed.
population_specificity: General population, with a focus on cardiovascular health.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether plasma phosphatidylcholine (PC) fatty acid composition could serve as a sensitive biomarker for n-3 fatty acid intake from fish oil across various supplementation doses in young, healthy women.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation significantly increased plasma PC EPA, DPA, and DHA in a dose-dependent manner and reduced plasma triacylglycerol concentrations by 16%. Flaxseed oil increased ALA, EPA, and DPA but did not affect DHA levels.
population_specificity: Young, healthy women
effective_dosage: 0.33–4.50 g EPA+DHA/day from fish oil or 5.90–6.60 g/day flaxseed oil

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature on the relationship between nutrition (including fish oil supplements) and osteoarthritis (OA) risk or progression to provide clinical guidance.
results_summary: The study found that increased consumption of long-chain omega-3 fatty acids from oily fish or fish oil supplements may benefit OA patients, particularly due to dietary-lipid modification and potential cholesterol reduction. However, evidence for vitamin D supplementation in OA was deemed unconvincing.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese patients with osteoarthritis or at risk of metabolic syndrome and type-2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the combined effects of vitamin D and omega-3 fatty acid from fish oil on clinical, metabolic, and genetic parameters in women with PCOS.
results_summary: Co-supplementation significantly improved mental health scores, reduced inflammatory markers (hs-CRP, MDA), increased antioxidant capacity (TAC), and modulated gene expression (downregulated IL-1, upregulated VEGF) in women with PCOS.
population_specificity: Women aged 18-40 with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).
effective_dosage: 2000 mg/day omega-3 fatty acid from fish oil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily oral supplementation of fish-derived n-3 fatty acids (3000 mg) improves symptoms and signs of dry eye disease compared to a placebo.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in symptom relief or ocular surface improvements between the fish-derived n-3 fatty acid group and the placebo group, with similar adverse event rates in both groups.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate-to-severe dry eye disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiobesity effects and efficacy of long-chain omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (n-3 PUFAs) in humans and animal models, particularly their role in weight management and metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: In animal models, n-3 PUFAs consistently reduced fat mass, especially in retroperitoneal and epididymal regions. In humans, n-3 PUFAs did not significantly aid weight loss but may help attenuate further weight gain and maintain weight loss by modulating lipid metabolism, regulating adipokines, and reducing adipose tissue inflammation.
population_specificity: Humans and animal models (specific human population not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fish oil supplementation could protect against the pro-allergic effects of traffic-related air pollution (TRAP) exposure in children.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation showed protective effects against allergic sensitization linked to TRAP exposure, particularly for house dust mite (HDM) and inhalant allergens, and improved lung function in a subgroup of children who did not change residences. The risk of positive HDM skin prick tests was significantly lower in the fish oil group compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Children from the Childhood Asthma Prevention Study (CAPS) birth cohort, aged 5 to 8 years.
study_duration: From early life to age 5 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a fish-based RUSF in preventing growth faltering and improving micronutrient status in Cambodian children compared to other supplements.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that children would consume the fish-based RUSF and caregivers would feed it to them, but full efficacy results were pending as the trial was ongoing at the time of the abstract.
population_specificity: Healthy Cambodian infants aged six to eleven months in peri-urban Phnom Penh.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (n-3 PUFAs) from fish oil influence skeletal muscle function, growth, and repair, particularly focusing on satellite cell activity.
results_summary: The review highlights that n-3 PUFAs may modulate molecular signaling for muscle growth and enhance satellite cell activity, potentially improving muscle repair, though human studies on this are limited.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on in vitro investigations and general mechanisms).

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine whether perioperative n-3 PUFA (fish oil) supplementation reduces postoperative cognitive decline in cardiac surgery patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in global cognition between the fish oil and placebo groups at 30 days post-surgery. Initial cognitive decline resolved by 30 days, suggesting no effect of n-3 PUFAs on postoperative cognitive function.
population_specificity: Cardiac surgery recipients (median age 62 years) at 9 U.S. tertiary care medical centers.
effective_dosage: Preoperative loading of 8-10 g over 2-5 days, followed by 2 g/day postoperatively until hospital discharge or postoperative day 10.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the prescription, administration appropriateness, and outcomes of Lenalidomide (LEN) in patients with myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) with del(5q), including erythroid and cytogenetic responses and disease evolution.
results_summary: The study found an overall erythroid response rate of 92.8% and cytogenetic remission in 22.6% of cases, with disease progression occurring in 15.6% of cases. Progression to AML was associated with clonal cytogenetic evolution, unlike progression to higher-risk MDS.
population_specificity: Patients with myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) with del(5q), recruited from 45 Haematological Centres in Italy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to measure the association between fish intake during pregnancy and the risk of recurrent spontaneous preterm birth among lean, overweight, and obese women.
results_summary: Among lean women, ≥1 serving of fish per week was associated with decreased frequency of spontaneous preterm birth compared to <1 serving, but this benefit was not observed in overweight or obese women, where fish intake was associated with higher probability of preterm birth.
population_specificity: 852 pregnant women (47% lean, 25% overweight, 28% obese) enrolled at 16-22.9 weeks gestation.
effective_dosage: ≥1 serving of fish per week vs. <1 serving per week.
study_duration: From enrollment (16-22.9 weeks gestation) until delivery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of maternal fish oil supplementation on birthweight and DNA methylation at the IGF-1 gene in offspring of women with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM).
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation was associated with a modest reduction in birthweight (250g lower) and higher DNA methylation at specific IGF-1 gene sites, though these effects did not persist in multivariate analysis. Cord blood IGF-1 levels were lower in the fish oil group, but methylation changes were not linked to birthweight.
population_specificity: Women with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) between 24-28 weeks of pregnancy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (fish oil liquid softgel, Ocean plus®).
study_duration: From 24-28 weeks of pregnancy until delivery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether omega-3 PUFA supplementation improves arteriovenous access outcomes in hemodialysis patients and assess potential safety concerns like bleeding risks.
results_summary: Omega-3 PUFA supplementation probably prevents primary patency loss but may have little or no effect on dialysis suitability failure, access abandonment, or need for interventions. Bleeding risk and gastrointestinal side-effects were uncertain.
population_specificity: Adults requiring hemodialysis via arteriovenous fistula or graft.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of fish oil supplementation on gene expression related to insulin, lipid metabolism, and inflammation in women with PCOS.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation upregulated PPAR-γ gene expression and downregulated IL-1 and IL-8 gene expression, but had no significant effect on LP(a), LDLR, GLUT-1, TNF-α, or TGF-β gene expression.
population_specificity: Women aged 18-40 with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).
effective_dosage: 1000 mg omega-3 fatty acids from fish oil twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of Ophiocephalus striatus extract on IGF-1 and albumin levels in elderly patients with hypoalbuminemia.
results_summary: The study found that supplementation with Ophiocephalus striatus extract significantly increased IGF-1 and albumin levels compared to placebo, with statistically significant improvements (p=0.002 for IGF-1, p=0.003 for albumin).
population_specificity: Malnourished elderly inpatients (≥60 years old) recovering from acute conditions, with Mini Nutritional Assessment score ≤23.5 and albumin level <3.5 g/dL.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of omega-3 PUFA in promoting "healthy adipocytes" in white adipose tissue (WAT) and its systemic metabolic benefits, particularly in obese and insulin-resistant states.
results_summary: Omega-3 PUFA improved immunometabolism in WAT, reduced inflammation, and enhanced lipid mediator synthesis, but its effects on insulin sensitivity in type 2 diabetic subjects were unclear. Combined interventions (e.g., calorie restriction or thiazolidinediones) showed potential but required further investigation.
population_specificity: Obese mice and type 2 diabetic subjects (human relevance inferred but not directly studied in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a marine omega-3 PUFA formulation (Omega3Q10) on blood pressure, cholesterol levels, and hypertension-related symptoms in older adults with hypertension and/or hypercholesterolemia.
results_summary: Omega3Q10 significantly reduced diastolic blood pressure and improved hypertension-related symptoms (headache, palpitations, and chest tightness) compared to soybean oil. Both supplements improved cholesterol levels (TC, LDL-C, HDL-C), but no significant group differences were found for these metrics.
population_specificity: Older adults with hypertension and/or hypercholesterolemia (n=97).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the anti-hyperlipidemic effects of omega-3 fatty acid supplements versus fresh fish consumption in patients with hyperlipidemia.
results_summary: Fresh fish consumption significantly improved lipid profiles more effectively than omega-3 supplements, reducing total cholesterol, triglycerides, and LDL levels while increasing HDL levels. Fish oil supplements also showed benefits but were less effective in modifying atherogenic indices and LDL levels.
population_specificity: 106 patients with hyperlipidemia (48 in fish oil group, 47 in fish group).
effective_dosage: 2 g/day of omega-3 capsules or 250 g trout fish twice weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of fish-oil derived n-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (n-3 PUFA) to improve muscle mass and function in older adults.
results_summary: Dietary supplementation with fish oil-derived n-3 PUFA was found to stimulate muscle protein synthesis, improve muscle mass and function in sedentary older adults, and enhance the effects of resistance exercise training on muscle strength. The exact mechanisms remain unclear.
population_specificity: Sedentary older adults and older adults undergoing resistance exercise training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (fish oils) could reduce vascular access failure in hemodialysis patients by promoting vascular access maturation and reducing stenosis and thrombosis.
results_summary: The study found mixed results regarding the efficacy of fish oil supplementation in improving arteriovenous fistula and graft outcomes, with some potential benefits attributed to its antiproliferative, antiaggregatory, anti-inflammatory, and vasodilatory effects.
population_specificity: Patients receiving hemodialysis with arteriovenous fistula or graft.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the adoption of novel fish oil-based lipid emulsions in neonatal nutrition practices for very low birth weight infants.
results_summary: Over half of the surveyed neonatal units use fish oil-based lipid emulsions, indicating their integration into clinical practice, but the abstract does not detail specific efficacy outcomes related to fish oil.
population_specificity: Very low birth weight infants (birth weight < 1,500 g and/or gestational age < 32 weeks) in Spanish tertiary neonatal hospitals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether genetic variations in the FADS gene cluster influence the effectiveness of fish oil supplementation in increasing LCPUFA levels in infants.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation significantly increased DHA levels in infants carrying two copies of the FADS1 haplotype minor alleles, but this effect was not observed in the placebo group. The study suggests that genetic factors may modulate the efficacy of fish oil in raising DHA levels.
population_specificity: Infants from birth to 6 months of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fish oil emulsion (FOE) could reduce hyperglycemia-induced oxidative stress and inflammation in monocytes/macrophages.
results_summary: FOE significantly increased antioxidant capacity and superoxide dismutase activity while reducing proinflammatory cytokine secretion, but it had no effect on oxidative damage to DNA, proteins, or lipids.
population_specificity: Monocytes/macrophages U937 system in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the association between marine omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acid (n-3 PUFA) intake from supplements, mainly cod liver oil, and coronary heart disease (CHD) mortality.
results_summary: Baseline n-3 PUFA intake from food and supplements was inversely associated with CHD mortality. Time-varying analysis showed significant risk reduction for n-3 PUFA supplement users (HR: 0.74), particularly in those who consistently used or started using these supplements. No association was found for non-n-3 PUFA supplement users or those who stopped using n-3 PUFA supplements.
population_specificity: 22,035 men and women (39-79 years) from the general population in Norfolk, UK, with low fish consumption.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether consuming fatty fish three times per week for 12 weeks could improve attention performance in adolescents compared to meat meals or n-3 LCPUFA supplements.
results_summary: The study found a small beneficial effect of fatty fish on processing speed compared to meat and supplements, though results were difficult to interpret due to low dietary compliance. The supplement group showed inferior improvement in total performance compared to the fish group.
population_specificity: Adolescents aged 14-15 years from eight secondary schools (n=426).
effective_dosage: Fatty fish meals three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the acceptability of a novel fish-based lipid nutrient supplement among Cambodian children and caregivers.
results_summary: The abstract does not report results, as it describes a pre-results trial design. The study planned to measure food consumption and caregiver preference rankings.
population_specificity: Healthy children aged 9-23 months (n=100) in periurban Phnom Penh, Cambodia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of fish oil (omega-3 PUFAs) in treating depression and explore its mechanisms of action, including anti-inflammatory effects and membrane interactions.
results_summary: Clinical trials indicate that fish oil supplementation is beneficial for managing depression, likely due to omega-3 PUFAs' anti-inflammatory properties and effects on cell membrane functions like lipid rafts and G-proteins. The review suggests promising but not definitive evidence for its antidepressant effects.
population_specificity: Patients with depression (specific subgroup not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fish oil supplementation and menstrual cycle phases (midfollicular vs. midluteal) could reduce exercise-induced muscle damage and delayed-onset muscle soreness (DOMS) in females.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation did not significantly attenuate muscle strength loss or markers like myoglobin and NF-Kβ, but higher estrogen levels during the midluteal phase showed a cytoprotective effect on muscle membranes. DOMS increased post-exercise regardless of supplementation or menstrual phase.
population_specificity: 22 physically active females (20.9 ± 1.4 years, 63.5 ± 9.0 kg, 165.2 ± 7.5 cm).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the prevalence of self-medication with dietary supplements, including fish oil (omega-3 fatty acids), among psoriasis patients and its impact on disease severity and quality of life.
results_summary: Omega-3 fatty acids or fish oil were used by 10.14% of psoriasis patients, but no significant differences in disease severity (PASI) or quality of life (DLQI) were found among patients consuming different supplements.
population_specificity: Psoriasis patients (n=138) and non-psoriasis controls (n=138), aged 21-91 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of DHA + EPA-enriched fish oil supplementation on metabolic parameters in patients with Type 2 diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in waist circumference and blood glucose levels in the fish oil group compared to placebo, suggesting beneficial metabolic effects.
population_specificity: 54 patients with Type 2 diabetes mellitus
effective_dosage: 520 mg of DHA + EPA-enriched fish oil daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether fish oil supplementation improves insulin sensitivity, particularly in individuals with metabolic disorders.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation showed no overall effect on insulin sensitivity in the general population but improved insulin sensitivity in individuals with metabolic disorders. Subgroup analyses found no significant differences based on insulin sensitivity measurement methods, omega-3 dosage, or intervention duration.
population_specificity: 672 participants, including individuals with and without metabolic disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of fatty fish on cognitive performance and mental health in adolescents through a randomized controlled trial.
results_summary: The study found higher levels of n-3 fatty acids, vitamin D, and n-6 fatty acids in fish meals compared to meat meals, but dietary compliance was lower in the Fish group than in the Meat and Supplement groups. The trial demonstrated feasibility but did not report specific cognitive or mental health outcomes in the abstract.
population_specificity: 478 adolescents (14-15-year-olds) from eight secondary schools in Norway.
effective_dosage: School meal lunches with fatty fish three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether daily supplementation of n-3 PUFAs (fish oil) could prevent postpartum depression in pregnant women at risk for PPD.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in the prevalence of postpartum depression or EPDS scores between the fish oil and control groups overall, though women with a history of depression in the fish oil group showed a modest reduction in EPDS scores during pregnancy.
population_specificity: Pregnant women in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, identified as at risk for postpartum depression.
effective_dosage: 1.8 g daily (1.08 g EPA and 0.72 g DHA).
study_duration: 16 weeks (from weeks 22-24 of gestation to 4-6 weeks postpartum).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether oxidized fish oil and high-quality fish oil differently affect lipoprotein subclasses and their lipid concentrations in healthy humans.
results_summary: High-quality fish oil reduced concentrations of intermediate-density lipoprotein (IDL) and LDL particles, as well as total lipids, phospholipids, cholesterol, and related compounds in these subclasses compared to oxidized fish oil and high-oleic sunflower oil. The study found that high-quality fish oil had more favorable effects on lipid composition.
population_specificity: Healthy humans (n=54)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of low-dose fish oil (FO) and marine phospholipids (MPL) formulations, with identical n-3-FA content, on weight stabilization, appetite, quality of life, and plasma fatty acid profiles in pancreatic cancer patients.
results_summary: Both FO and MPL supplementation at low doses (0.3 g n-3-FA/day) similarly stabilized weight and appetite in pancreatic cancer patients, with MPL being slightly better tolerated and causing fewer side effects. The study suggests further investigation into MPL for improving quality of life in cancer patients, possibly combined with medium-chain triglycerides (MCT).
population_specificity: Pancreatic cancer patients (n=60, with 31 completing the study).
effective_dosage: 0.3 g of n-3-fatty acids per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of fish oil supplements on haemostasis and bleeding risk, and to determine if discontinuation prior to surgery is necessary.
results_summary: Fish oil supplements reduced platelet aggregation in healthy subjects but did not increase bleeding risk or blood transfusions in surgical patients. The biochemical effect on platelets did not translate to clinically significant bleeding.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects and patients undergoing surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evidence for using mannitol and other drugs in treating ciguatera fish poisoning over the past four decades.
results_summary: The study found mixed evidence for mannitol's effectiveness, with some uncontrolled case series supporting its use but one small RCT showing no significant benefit. Other treatments like amitriptyline and gabapentin showed symptomatic improvement but required long-term use and lacked superiority to mannitol.
population_specificity: Individuals with ciguatera fish poisoning.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cardiovascular benefits of long-chain n-3 PUFA from fish and the potential need for supplementation in populations with low intake, such as vegans and vegetarians.
results_summary: The study suggests that long-chain n-3 PUFA from fish may have systemic pleiotropic effects, including anti-inflammatory properties and cardiovascular benefits, but the clinical impact of low tissue levels remains unclear. Randomized controlled trials in populations with low baseline n-3 PUFA status are lacking.
population_specificity: UK population, particularly vegans and vegetarians with low or no fish intake.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of omega-3 supplements on cardiovascular outcomes, including mortality, myocardial infarction, and stroke.
results_summary: The study found that omega-3 supplements do not consistently benefit cardiovascular protection, with uncertainty regarding their clear advantage in cardiovascular disease.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population inferred from randomized controlled trials).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the deregulation of the innate immune system in patients with Alzheimer's disease and mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
results_summary: The study found that the innate immune system in these patients is deregulated, with highly increased or decreased transcription of inflammatory genes and consistently depressed phagocytosis of amyloid-β.
population_specificity: Patients with Alzheimer's disease and mild cognitive impairment (MCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of green tea extract (GTE) on sturgeon hybrids fed oxidized fish oil (OFO) by assessing growth performance, lipid metabolism, and antioxidant status.
results_summary: Feeding with oxidized fish oil did not affect growth but negatively impacted lipid metabolism and antioxidant status. Green tea extract improved growth indices slightly and moderated the adverse effects of oxidized oil on lipid metabolism and antioxidant enzymes.
population_specificity: Sturgeon hybrid of Sterlet (Huso huso ♀ × Acipenser ruthenus ♂) with an initial weight of 212.6 ± 0.7 g.
effective_dosage: Green tea extract at 0, 5, and 100 mg/kg diet; oxidized fish oil at 0%, 50%, and 100% replacement of lipid content.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the associations between prenatal fish oil supplementation (before and during pregnancy) and subsequent child neurodevelopment.
results_summary: The study found that prenatal fish oil supplementation was associated with a significantly lower risk of failing the problem-solving domain in child development up to 3 years of age, particularly among singletons and girls. No significant gender interaction was observed, but stronger associations were noted in girls.
population_specificity: Mother-child pairs from the Upstate KIDS Study (children born between 2008 and 2010, including 3807 singletons and 2038 twins).
study_duration: Supplementation before and during pregnancy (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of fish oil on the occurrence of atrial fibrillation (AF) following coronary artery bypass graft surgery (CABG).
results_summary: Fish oil consumption led to a shorter time to AF improvement (though not statistically significant), reduced AF incidence by approximately 5.7% (borderline significance), and significantly decreased ICU and hospital stay durations.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing coronary artery bypass graft surgery (CABG).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether omega-3 fatty acid (n-3 FA) supplementation during soccer-specific training improves strength, speed, power, and anaerobic endurance in competitive soccer players.
results_summary: The study found no improvement in strength, power, or sprint performance with n-3 FA supplementation, but anaerobic endurance (Yo-Yo test) improved significantly in the n-3 FA group compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Competitive soccer players (n=26)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current knowledge about risk factors for vitamin D deficiency in the elderly, including the role of dietary factors like small sea fish consumption.
results_summary: The study found that reduced consumption of small sea fish contributes to vitamin D deficiency in elderly populations, particularly in moderate climate countries, and highlighted sociodemographic and health factors exacerbating deficiency.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals, especially women, living in moderate climate countries.
